fields.name: agentRole
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of a role of an Agent.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary for the roles appropriate to the class of resource an AgentRole is related to.

fields.name: agentRoleIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the role of an Agent.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: agentRoleVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for agentRole is given.

fields.name: agentRoleOrder
fields.description: The numerical position of an AgentRole in a set of AgentRoles that have the same combination of agentRoleTargetID and agentRoleTargetType.
fields.comments: One could use agentRoleOrder to create an ordered list of collectors for a dwc:MaterialEntity, for example. The first would have agentRoleOrder=1, the second would have agentRoleOrder=2.

fields.name: agentRoleDate
fields.description: The interval during which an AgentRole was in effect.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: assertionID
fields.description: An identifier for an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: eventID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: assertionType
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of an Assertion.
fields.examples: `mass`; `mean mass`; `weight standard deviation`; `minimum organism quantity`; `water temperature`; `salinity`

fields.name: assertionTypeIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionTypeVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for assertionType is given.

fields.name: assertionMadeDate
fields.description: The date on which an Assertion was created.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: assertionEffectiveDate
fields.description: The date on which the state or measurement of an Assertion was deemed to first be in effect.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: assertionValue
fields.description: An asserted value, if it is not numeric.

fields.name: assertionValueIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the value of an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionValueVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary where the definition of the value for assertionValue is given.

fields.name: assertionValueNumeric
fields.description: An asserted value, if it is numeric.

fields.name: assertionUnit
fields.description: The units associated with the value in assertionValueNumeric.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Ontology of Units of Measure http://www.wurvoc.org/vocabularies/om-1.8/ of SI units, derived units, or other non-SI units accepted for use within the SI. For units that are composed of multiple parts, use the patterns as given in "A Primer for Communicating Mathematics via Plain Text" (https://cse.sc.edu/~fenner/latex-ASCII.pdf) by Stephen Fenner (e.g., `g/cm^3` for grams per cubic centimeter). For other units, provide the value as a recognizable standard (e.g., '%') or written out in full and in the plural (e.g., `individuals`). It is fine to provide non-SI units in the original language of the dataset.

fields.name: assertionUnitIRI
fields.description: The IRI for the units of an assertionValueNumeric.

fields.name: assertionUnitVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in assertionUnit is given.

fields.name: assertionBy
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who made an Assertion.
fields.examples: `José E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson`; `FMNH`

fields.name: assertionByID
fields.description: An identifier for an Agent who made an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
fields.examples: `https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097` (for an individual); `https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097 | https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0098` (for a list of people)

fields.name: assertionProtocol
fields.description: The names of, references to, or descriptions of the methods or protocols used in making an Assertion.

fields.name: assertionProtocolID
fields.description: An identifier for a Protocol used to make an Assertion.

fields.name: assertionCitation
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261`; `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

fields.name: assertionRemarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about an Assertion.

fields.name: citationID
fields.description: An identifier for a Citation.

fields.name: eventID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: citationType
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of a Citation.

fields.name: citationTypeIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Citation.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: citationTypeVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in citationType is given.

fields.name: bibliographicCitation
fields.description: A bibliographic reference for the resource.
fields.comments: From Dublin Core, 'Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible.' The intended usage of this term in Darwin Core is to provide the preferred way to cite the resource itself. Note that the intended usage of dcterms:references in Darwin Core, by contrast, is to point to the definitive source representation of the resource, if one is available.
fields.examples: `Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, UC Berkeley. MVZ Mammal Collection (Arctos). Record ID: http://arctos.database.museum/guid/MVZ:Mamm:165861?seid=101356. Source: http://ipt.vertnet.org:8080/ipt/resource.do?r=mvz_mammal.` (Occurrence example); `https://www.gbif.org/species/2439608 Source: GBIF Taxonomic Backbone` (Taxon example); `Rand, K.M., Logerwell, E.A. The first demersal trawl survey of benthic fish and invertebrates in the Beaufort Sea since the late 1970s. Polar Biol 34, 475–488 (2011). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00300-010-0900-2` (Event example)

fields.name: pageNumber
fields.description: The number of the page on which the citation occurs in the cited reference.
fields.comments: From Dublin Core, 'Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible.' The intended usage of this term in Darwin Core is to provide the preferred way to cite the resource itself. Note that the intended usage of dcterms:references in Darwin Core, by contrast, is to point to the definitive source representation of the resource, if one is available.

fields.name: referenceID
fields.description: An identifier for the reference in which a Citation occurs.

fields.name: referenceType
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of a reference.

fields.name: referenceTypeIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of reference.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: referenceTypeVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in referenceType is given.

fields.name: referenceYear
fields.description: The year the reference in a Citation was published.

fields.name: isPeerReviewed
fields.description: An indication of whether the reference for a Citation was peer reviewed.

fields.name: citationRemarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a Citation.

fields.name: identifier
fields.description: An unambiguous reference to a resource within a given context.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to identify a resource by means of a string conforming to a formal identification system.

fields.name: eventID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: identifierType
fields.description: The category or system that best matches the nature of an Identifier.

fields.name: identifierTypeIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Identifier.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: identifierTypeVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in identifierType is given.

fields.name: identifierLanguage
fields.description: A language in which an Identifier is presented.
fields.comments: Recommended best prectice is to use an ISO639-2 three-letter language code.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.description: An identifier for a Media instance.

fields.name: eventID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategory
fields.description: A term to describe the content of the image by a value from a controlled vocabulary.
fields.comments: Controlled vocabulary of subjects to support broad classification of media items. Terms from various controlled vocabularies may be used. AC-recommended vocabularies are preferred and MAY be unqualified literals (not a full URI). For terms from other vocabularies either a precise URI SHOULD be used, or, as long as all unqualified terms in all vocabularies are unique, metadata SHOULD provide the source vocabularies using the Subject Category Vocabulary term. The value SHOULD be a string, whose text can also be in the form of a URL. These guidelines on value format are less restrictive than is specified by the IPTC guidelines.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategoryIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the subject category of the Media instance.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategoryVocabulary
fields.description: Any vocabulary or formal classification from which terms in the Subject Category have been drawn.
fields.comments: The AC recommended vocabularies do not need to be cited here. There is no required linkage between individual Subject Category terms and the vocabulary; the mechanism is intended to support discovery of the normative URI for a term, but not guarantee it.

fields.name: protocolID
fields.description: An identifier for a Protocol.

fields.name: eventID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: eventID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: parentEventID
fields.description: An identifier for a broader dwc:Event that groups this and potentially other dwc:Events.

fields.name: preferredEventName
fields.description: The name of a dwc:Event preferred in searches and results.

fields.name: eventType
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: datasetName
fields.description: A name for a dataset from which data originated.

fields.name: datasetID
fields.description: An identifier for a dataset from which data originated.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: fieldNumber
fields.description: An identifier given to a dwc:Event in the field.
fields.comments: Often serves as a link between field notes and a dwc:Event.

fields.name: eventConductedBy
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations responsible for conducting or recording a dwc:Event.
fields.examples: `José E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson`; `FMNH`

fields.name: eventConductedByID
fields.description: An identifier for the Agent responsible for conducting or recording a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: eventDate
fields.description: The date or time interval during which a dwc:Event occurred.
fields.comments: For gathering dwc:Events, this is the date-time when the gathering took place.
fields.examples: `1963-03-08T14:07-06:00` (8 Mar 1963 at 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `2009-02-20T08:40Z` (20 February 2009 8:40am UTC); `2018-08-29T15:19` (3:19pm local time on 29 August 2018); `1809-02-12` (some time during 12 February 1809); `1906-06` (some time in June 1906); `1971` (some time in the year 1971); `2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z` (some time during the interval between 1 March 2007 1pm UTC and 11 May 2008 3:30pm UTC); `1900/1909` (some time during the interval between the beginning of the year 1900 and the end of the year 1909); `2007-11-13/15` (some time in the interval between 13 November 2007 and 15 November 2007)

fields.name: eventTime
fields.description: The time or interval during which a dwc:Event occurred.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a time of day that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.
fields.examples: `14:07-06:00` (2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `08:40:21Z` (8:40:21am UTC); `13:00:00Z/15:30:00Z` (the interval between 1pm UTC and 3:30pm UTC)

fields.name: startDayOfYear
fields.description: The earliest integer day of the year on which a dwc:Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
fields.examples: `1` (1 January); `32` (1 February); `366` (31 December); `365` (30 December in a leap year, 31 December in a non-leap year)

fields.name: endDayOfYear
fields.description: The latest integer day of the year on which a dwc:Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
fields.examples: `1` (1 January); `32` (1 February); `366` (31 December); `365` (30 December in a leap year, 31 December in a non-leap year)

fields.name: year
fields.description: The four-digit year in which a dwc:Event occurred, according to the Common Era Calendar.

fields.name: month
fields.description: The integer month in which a dwc:Event occurred.

fields.name: day
fields.description: The integer day of the month on which a dwc:Event occurred.

fields.name: verbatimEventDate
fields.description: The verbatim original representation of the date and time information for a dwc:Event.

fields.name: verbatimLocality
fields.description: The original textual description of a dcterms:Location of a dwc:Event.
fields.examples: `25 km NNE Bariloche por R. Nac. 237`

fields.name: verbatimElevation
fields.description: The original description of the elevation (altitude, usually above sea level) of a dcterms:Location.

fields.name: verbatimDepth
fields.description: The original description of the depth below a local surface.

fields.name: verbatimCoordinates
fields.description: The verbatim original spatial coordinates of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

fields.name: verbatimLatitude
fields.description: The verbatim original latitude of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

fields.name: verbatimLongitude
fields.description: The verbatim original longitude of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

fields.name: verbatimCoordinateSystem
fields.description: The coordinate format for dwc:verbatimLatitude and dwc:verbatimLongitude or dwc:verbatimCoordinates.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: verbatimSRS
fields.description: The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which coordinates given in dwc:verbatimLatitude and dwc:verbatimLongitude, or dwc:verbatimCoordinates are based.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `unknown`.

fields.name: georeferenceVerificationStatus
fields.description: A categorical description of the extent to which the georeference has been verified to represent the best possible spatial description for the dcterms:Location of a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.examples: `unable to georeference`; `requires georeference`; `requires verification`; `verified by data custodian`; `verified by contributor`

fields.name: habitat
fields.description: A category or description of the habitat in which a dwc:Event occurred.

fields.name: sampleSizeValue
fields.description: A numeric value for a measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling dwc:Event.
fields.comments: A dwc:sampleSizeValue must have a corresponding dwc:sampleSizeUnit.

fields.name: sampleSizeUnit
fields.description: The unit of measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling dwc:Event.
fields.comments: A dwc:sampleSizeUnit must have a corresponding dwc:sampleSizeValue, e.g., `5` for dwc:sampleSizeValue with `metre` for dwc:sampleSizeUnit.

fields.name: eventEffort
fields.description: The amount of effort expended during a dwc:Event.
fields.examples: `40 trap-nights`; `10 observer-hours`; `10 km by foot`; `30 km by car`

fields.name: fieldNotes
fields.description: One of a) an indicator of the existence of, b) a reference to (publication, URI), or c) the text of notes taken in the field about a dwc:Event.

fields.name: eventCitation
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261`; `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

fields.name: eventRemarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Event.
fields.examples: `After the recent rains the river is nearly at flood stage.`

fields.name: locationID
fields.description: An identifier a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: higherGeographyID
fields.description: An identifier for the geographic region within which the dcterms:Location occurred.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
fields.examples: `http://vocab.getty.edu/tgn/1002002`  (Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur, Territorio Nacional de la Tierra del Fuego, Argentina).

fields.name: higherGeography
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of geographic names less specific than the information captured in dwc:locality.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `), with terms in order from least specific to most specific.
fields.examples: `North Atlantic Ocean`; `South America | Argentina | Patagonia | Parque Nacional Nahuel Huapi | Neuquén | Los Lagos` with accompanying values `South America` (continent) `Argentina` (country), `Neuquén` (first order division), and `Los Lagos` (second order division)

fields.name: continent
fields.description: The name of the continent in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: waterBody
fields.description: The name of the water body in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

fields.name: islandGroup
fields.description: The name of the island group in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

fields.name: island
fields.description: The name of the island on or near which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

fields.name: country
fields.description: The name of the country or major administrative unit in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: countryCode
fields.description: The standard code for the country in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 country code. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: stateProvince
fields.description: The name of the next smaller administrative region than country (state, province, canton, department, region, etc.) in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if a dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if a dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: county
fields.description: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than dwc:stateProvince (county, shire, department, etc.) in which the dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: municipality
fields.description: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than county (city, municipality, etc.) in which a dcterms:Location occurs. Do not use this term for a nearby named place that does not contain the actual location.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if a dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if a dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term `higherGeography` or in the term `locality`, or both.

fields.name: locality
fields.description: The specific description of the place.
fields.comments: Less specific geographic information can be provided in other geographic terms (higherGeography, continent, country, stateProvince, county, municipality, waterBody, island, islandGroup). This term may contain information modified from the original to correct perceived errors or standardize the description.
fields.examples: `Bariloche, 25 km NNE via Ruta Nacional 40 (=Ruta 237)`; `Queets Rainforest, Olympic National Park`

fields.name: minimumElevationInMeters
fields.description: The lower limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.

fields.name: maximumElevationInMeters
fields.description: The upper limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.

fields.name: verticalDatum
fields.description: The vertical datum used as the reference upon which the values in the elevation terms are based.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: minimumDepthInMeters
fields.description: The lesser depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in meters.

fields.name: maximumDepthInMeters
fields.description: The greater depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in meters.

fields.name: minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters
fields.description: The lesser distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
fields.examples: `-1.5` (below the surface); `4.2` (above the surface); For a 1.5 meter sediment core from the bottom of a lake (at depth 20m) at 300m elevation: verbatimElevation: `300m` minimumElevationInMeters: `300`, maximumElevationInMeters: `300`, verbatimDepth: `20m`, minimumDepthInMeters: `20`, maximumDepthInMeters: `20`, minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `0`, maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `-1.5`.

fields.name: maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters
fields.description: The greater distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
fields.examples: `-1.5` (below the surface); `4.2` (above the surface); For a 1.5 meter sediment core from the bottom of a lake (at depth 20m) at 300m elevation: verbatimElevation: `300m` minimumElevationInMeters: `300`, maximumElevationInMeters: `300`, verbatimDepth: `20m`, minimumDepthInMeters: `20`, maximumDepthInMeters: `20`, minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `0`, maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `-1.5`.

fields.name: locationRemarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dcterms:Location.

fields.name: decimalLatitude
fields.description: The geographic latitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in dwc:geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Positive values are north of the Equator, negative values are south of it. Legal values lie between -90 and 90, inclusive.

fields.name: decimalLongitude
fields.description: The geographic longitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in dwc:geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Positive values are east of the Greenwich Meridian, negative values are west of it. Legal values lie between -180 and 180, inclusive.

fields.name: geodeticDatum
fields.description: The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which the geographic coordinates given in dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude as based.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `unknown`.

fields.name: coordinateUncertaintyInMeters
fields.description: The horizontal distance (in meters) from the given dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude describing the smallest circle containing the whole of the dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Leave the value empty if the uncertainty is unknown, cannot be estimated, or is not applicable (because there are no coordinates). Zero is not a valid value for this term.
fields.examples: `30` (reasonable lower limit on or after 2000-05-01 of a GPS reading under good conditions if the actual precision was not recorded at the time); `100` (reasonable lower limit before 2000-05-01 of a GPS reading under good conditions if the actual precision was not recorded at the time); `71` (uncertainty for a UTM coordinate having 100 meter precision and a known spatial reference system)

fields.name: coordinatePrecision
fields.description: A decimal representation of the precision of the coordinates given in a dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude.
fields.examples: `0.00001` (normal GPS limit for decimal degrees); `0.000278` (nearest second); `0.01667` (nearest minute); `1.0` (nearest degree)

fields.name: pointRadiusSpatialFit
fields.description: The ratio of the area of the point-radius (dwc:decimalLatitude, dwc:decimalLongitude, dwc:coordinateUncertaintyInMeters) to the area of the true (original, or most specific) spatial representation of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Legal values are 0, greater than or equal to 1, or undefined. A value of 1 is an exact match or 100% overlap. A value of 0 should be used if the given point-radius does not completely contain the original representation. The pointRadiusSpatialFit is undefined (and should be left empty) if the original representation is any geometry without area (e.g., a point or polyline) and without uncertainty and the given georeference is not that same geometry (without uncertainty). If both the original and the given georeference are the same point, the pointRadiusSpatialFit is 1. Detailed explanations with graphical examples can be found in the Georeferencing Best Practices, Chapman and Wieczorek, 2020 (https://doi.org/10.15468/doc-gg7h-s853).

fields.name: footprintWKT
fields.description: A Well-Known Text (WKT) representation of the shape (footprint, geometry) that defines a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: A dcterms:Location may have both a point-radius representation (see dwc:decimalLatitude) and a footprint representation, and they may differ from each other.
fields.examples: `POLYGON ((10 20, 11 20, 11 21, 10 21, 10 20))` (the one-degree bounding box with opposite corners at longitude=10, latitude=20 and longitude=11, latitude=21)

fields.name: footprintSRS
fields.description: The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which the geometry given in dwc:footprintWKT is based.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `unknown`. It is also permitted to provide the SRS in Well-Known-Text, especially if no EPSG code provides the necessary values for the attributes of the SRS. Do not use this term to describe the SRS of a dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude, nor of any verbatim coordinates - use dwc:geodeticDatum and dwc:verbatimSRS instead.
fields.examples: `epsg:4326`; `GEOGCS['GCS_WGS_1984', DATUM['D_WGS_1984', SPHEROID['WGS_1984',6378137,298.257223563]], PRIMEM['Greenwich',0], UNIT['Degree',0.0174532925199433]]` (WKT for the standard WGS84 Spatial Reference System EPSG:4326)

fields.name: footprintSpatialFit
fields.description: The ratio of the area of the footprint (footprintWKT) to the area of the true (original, or most specific) spatial representation of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Legal values are 0, greater than or equal to 1, or undefined. A value of 1 is an exact match or 100% overlap. A value of 0 should be used if the given footprint does not completely contain the original representation. The dwc:footprintSpatialFit is undefined (and should be left empty) if the original representation is any geometry without area (e.g., a point or polyline) and without uncertainty and the given georeference is not that same geometry (without uncertainty). If both the original and the given georeference are the same point, a dwc:footprintSpatialFit is 1.

fields.name: georeferencedBy
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who determined a georeference (spatial representation) for a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

fields.name: georeferencedByID
fields.description: An identifier for the Agent who georeferenced a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: georeferencedDate
fields.description: The date on which a dcterms:Location was georeferenced.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: georeferenceProtocol
fields.description: A description or reference to the methods used to determine the spatial footprint, coordinates, and uncertainties.
fields.examples: `Georeferencing Quick Reference Guide (Zermoglio et al. 2020, https://doi.org/10.35035/e09p-h128)`

fields.name: georeferenceProtocolID
fields.description: An identifier for a Protocol used to georeference a dwc:Event.

fields.name: georeferenceSources
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of maps, gazetteers, or other resources used to georeference a dcterms:Location, described specifically enough to allow anyone in the future to use the same resources.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `https://www.geonames.org/`; `USGS 1:24000 Florence Montana Quad 1967 | Terrametrics 2008 on Google Earth`; `GeoLocate`

fields.name: georeferenceRemarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a spatial description determination, explaining assumptions made in addition or opposition to the those formalized in the method referred to in dwc:georeferenceProtocol.

fields.name: informationWithheld
fields.description: Additional information that exists, but that has not been shared in the given record.
fields.examples: `location information not given for endangered species`; `collector identities withheld | ask about tissue samples`

fields.name: dataGeneralizations
fields.description: Actions taken to make the shared data less specific or complete than in its original form. Suggests that alternative data of higher quality may be available on request.
fields.examples: `coordinates generalized from original GPS coordinates to the nearest half degree grid cell`

fields.name: preferredSpatialRepresentation
fields.description: An indication of which spatial representation best represents the dcterms:Location.

fields.name: geneticAnalysisID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticAnalysis.

fields.name: eventID
fields.description: An identifier for an Event.

fields.name: geneticProtocolID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticProtocol.

fields.name: geneticSequenceID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticSequence.

fields.name: materialEntityID
fields.description: An identifier for a MaterialEntity.

fields.name: readCount
fields.description: The number of reads for the sequence in the analysis.

fields.name: totalReadCount
fields.description: The total number of reads in the analysis.

fields.name: geneticProtocolID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticProtocol.

fields.name: samp_name
fields.description: Sample Name is a name that you choose for the sample. It can have any format, but we suggest that you make it concise, unique and consistent within your lab, and as informative as possible. Every Sample Name from a single Submitter must be unique.

fields.name: project_name
fields.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

fields.name: experimental_factor
fields.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

fields.name: samp_taxon_id
fields.description: NCBI taxon id of the sample. Maybe be a single taxon or mixed taxa sample. Use "synthetic metagenome" for mock community/positive controls, or "blank sample" for negative controls

fields.name: neg_cont_type
fields.description: The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation

fields.name: pos_cont_type
fields.description: The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive

fields.name: env_broad_scale
fields.description: In this field, report which major environmental system your sample or specimen came from. The systems identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. were you in the desert or a rainforest?). We recommend using subclasses of ENVO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. Format (one term): termLabel [termID], Format (multiple terms): termLabel [termID]|termLabel [termID]|termLabel [termID]. Example: Annotating a water sample from the photic zone in middle of the Atlantic Ocean, consider: oceanic epipelagic zone biome [ENVO:01000033]. Example: Annotating a sample from the Amazon rainforest consider: tropical moist broadleaf forest biome [ENVO:01000228]. If needed, request new terms on the ENVO tracker, identified here: http://www.obofoundry.org/ontology/envo.html

fields.name: env_local_scale
fields.description: In this field, report the entity or entities which are in your sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. Please use terms that are present in ENVO and which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for env_broad_scale. Format (one term): termLabel [termID]; Format (multiple terms): termLabel [termID]|termLabel [termID]|termLabel [termID]. Example: Annotating a pooled sample taken from various vegetation layers in a forest consider: canopy [ENVO:00000047]|herb and fern layer [ENVO:01000337]|litter layer [ENVO:01000338]|understory [01000335]|shrub layer [ENVO:01000336]. If needed, request new terms on the ENVO tracker, identified here: http://www.obofoundry.org/ontology/envo.html

fields.name: env_medium
fields.description: In this field, report which environmental material or materials (pipe separated) immediately surrounded your sample or specimen prior to sampling, using one or more subclasses of ENVO’s environmental material class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483. Format (one term): termLabel [termID]; Format (multiple terms): termLabel [termID]|termLabel [termID]|termLabel [termID]. Example: Annotating a fish swimming in the upper 100 m of the Atlantic Ocean, consider: ocean water [ENVO:00002151]. Example: Annotating a duck on a pond consider: pond water [ENVO:00002228]|air ENVO_00002005. If needed, request new terms on the ENVO tracker, identified here: http://www.obofoundry.org/ontology/envo.html

fields.name: subspecf_gen_lin
fields.description: This should provide further information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism by recording additional information e.g. serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. It can also contain alternative taxonomic information. It should contain both the lineage name, and the lineage rank, i.e. biovar:abc123

fields.name: ploidy
fields.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2018-03-27) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

fields.name: num_replicons
fields.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote

fields.name: extrachrom_elements
fields.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids)

fields.name: estimated_size
fields.description: The estimated size of the genome prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period.

fields.name: ref_biomaterial
fields.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report

fields.name: source_mat_id
fields.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain ´UAM:Herps:14´ , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

fields.name: pathogenicity
fields.description: To what is the entity pathogenic

fields.name: biotic_relationship
fields.description: Description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associated with. E.g., parasite on species X; mutualist with species Y. The target organism is the subject of the relationship, and the other organism(s) is the object

fields.name: specific_host
fields.description: If there is a host involved, please provide its taxid (or environmental if not actually isolated from the dead or alive host - i.e. a pathogen could be isolated from a swipe of a bench etc) and report whether it is a laboratory or natural host)

fields.name: host_spec_range
fields.description: The NCBI taxonomy identifier of the specific host if it is known

fields.name: host_disease_stat
fields.description: List of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from the DO (Human Disease Ontology) at https://www.disease-ontology.org, non-human host diseases are free text

fields.name: trophic_level
fields.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

fields.name: propagation
fields.description: This field is specific to different taxa. For phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group, for eukaryotes: sexual/asexual (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice

fields.name: encoded_traits
fields.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

fields.name: rel_to_oxygen
fields.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

fields.name: isol_growth_condt
fields.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material

fields.name: samp_collec_device
fields.description: The device used to collect an environmental sample. This field accepts terms listed under environmental sampling device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO). This field also accepts terms listed under specimen collection device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0002094).
fields.examples: environmental swab sampling, biopsy, niskin bottle, push core

fields.name: samp_collec_method
fields.description: The method employed for collecting the sample
fields.examples: environmental swab sampling, biopsy, niskin bottle, push core

fields.name: samp_mat_process
fields.description: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI
fields.examples: filtering of seawater, storing samples in ethanol

fields.name: size_frac
fields.description: Filtering pore size used in sample preparation

fields.name: samp_size
fields.description: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected

fields.name: samp_vol_we_dna_ext
fields.description: Volume (ml) or mass (g) of total collected sample processed for DNA extraction. Note: total sample collected should be entered under the term Sample Size (MIXS:0000001).

fields.name: source_uvig
fields.description: Type of dataset from which the UViG was obtained

fields.name: virus_enrich_appr
fields.description: List of approaches used to enrich the sample for viruses, if any

fields.name: nucl_acid_ext
fields.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample

fields.name: nucl_acid_amp
fields.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the enzymatic amplification (PCR, TMA, NASBA) of specific nucleic acids

fields.name: lib_size
fields.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

fields.name: lib_reads_seqd
fields.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

fields.name: lib_layout
fields.description: Specify whether to expect single, paired, or other configuration of reads

fields.name: lib_vector
fields.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

fields.name: lib_screen
fields.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating libraries

fields.name: target_gene
fields.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

fields.name: target_subfragment
fields.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

fields.name: pcr_primers
fields.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

fields.name: mid
fields.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

fields.name: adapters
fields.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

fields.name: pcr_cond
fields.description: Description of reaction conditions and components of PCR in the form of ´initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...´

fields.name: seq_meth
fields.description: Sequencing method used; e.g. Sanger, ABI-solid

fields.name: seq_quality_check
fields.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA,ENA or DRA

fields.name: chimera_check
fields.description: A chimeric sequence, or chimera for short, is a sequence comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences. Chimeras are usually PCR artifacts thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to a foreign DNA strand and is copied to completion in the following PCR cycles. The point at which the chimeric sequence changes from one parent to the next is called the breakpoint or conversion point

fields.name: tax_ident
fields.description: The phylogenetic marker(s) used to assign an organism name to the SAG or MAG

fields.name: assembly_qual
fields.description: The assembly quality category is based on sets of criteria outlined for each assembly quality category. For MISAG/MIMAG; Finished: Single, validated, contiguous sequence per replicon without gaps or ambiguities with a consensus error rate equivalent to Q50 or better. High Quality Draft:Multiple fragments where gaps span repetitive regions. Presence of the 23S, 16S and 5S rRNA genes and at least 18 tRNAs. Medium Quality Draft:Many fragments with little to no review of assembly other than reporting of standard assembly statistics. Low Quality Draft:Many fragments with little to no review of assembly other than reporting of standard assembly statistics. Assembly statistics include, but are not limited to total assembly size, number of contigs, contig N50/L50, and maximum contig length. For MIUVIG; Finished: Single, validated, contiguous sequence per replicon without gaps or ambiguities, with extensive manual review and editing to annotate putative gene functions and transcriptional units. High-quality draft genome: One or multiple fragments, totaling ≥ 90% of the expected genome or replicon sequence or predicted complete. Genome fragment(s): One or multiple fragments, totalling < 90% of the expected genome or replicon sequence, or for which no genome size could be estimated

fields.name: assembly_name
fields.description: Name/version of the assembly provided by the submitter that is used in the genome browsers and in the community

fields.name: assembly_software
fields.description: Tool(s) used for assembly, including version number and parameters

fields.name: annot
fields.description: Tool used for annotation, or for cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

fields.name: number_contig
fields.description: Total number of contigs in the cleaned/submitted assembly that makes up a given genome, SAG, MAG, or UViG

fields.name: feat_pred
fields.description: Method used to predict UViGs features such as ORFs, integration site, etc.

fields.name: ref_db
fields.description: List of database(s) used for ORF annotation, along with version number and reference to website or publication

fields.name: sim_search_meth
fields.description: Tool used to compare ORFs with database, along with version and cutoffs used

fields.name: tax_class
fields.description: Method used for taxonomic classification, along with reference database used, classification rank, and thresholds used to classify new genomes
fields.examples: vConTACT vContact2 (references from NCBI RefSeq v83, genus rank classification, default parameters)

fields.name: _16s_recover
fields.description: Can a 16S gene be recovered from the submitted SAG or MAG?

fields.name: _16s_recover_software
fields.description: Tools used for 16S rRNA gene extraction

fields.name: trnas
fields.description: The total number of tRNAs identified from the SAG or MAG

fields.name: trna_ext_software
fields.description: Tools used for tRNA identification

fields.name: compl_score
fields.description: Completeness score is typically based on either the fraction of markers found as compared to a database or the percent of a genome found as compared to a closely related reference genome. High Quality Draft: >90%, Medium Quality Draft: >50%, and Low Quality Draft: < 50% should have the indicated completeness scores

fields.name: compl_software
fields.description: Tools used for completion estimate, i.e. checkm, anvi´o, busco

fields.name: compl_appr
fields.description: The approach used to determine the completeness of a given SAG or MAG, which would typically make use of a set of conserved marker genes or a closely related reference genome. For UViG completeness, include reference genome or group used, and contig feature suggesting a complete genome
fields.examples: other: UViG length compared to the average length of reference genomes from the P22virus genus (NCBI RefSeq v83)

fields.name: contam_score
fields.description: The contamination score is based on the fraction of single-copy genes that are observed more than once in a query genome. The following scores are acceptable for; High Quality Draft: < 5%, Medium Quality Draft: < 10%, Low Quality Draft: < 10%. Contamination must be below 5% for a SAG or MAG to be deposited into any of the public databases

fields.name: contam_screen_input
fields.description: The type of sequence data used as input

fields.name: contam_screen_param
fields.description: Specific parameters used in the decontamination sofware, such as reference database, coverage, and kmers. Combinations of these parameters may also be used, i.e. kmer and coverage, or reference database and kmer

fields.name: decontam_software
fields.description: Tool(s) used in contamination screening

fields.name: sort_tech
fields.description: Method used to sort/isolate cells or particles of interest

fields.name: single_cell_lysis_appr
fields.description: Method used to free DNA from interior of the cell(s) or particle(s)

fields.name: single_cell_lysis_prot
fields.description: Name of the kit or standard protocol used for cell(s) or particle(s) lysis

fields.name: wga_amp_appr
fields.description: Method used to amplify genomic DNA in preparation for sequencing

fields.name: wga_amp_kit
fields.description: Kit used to amplify genomic DNA in preparation for sequencing

fields.name: bin_param
fields.description: The parameters that have been applied during the extraction of genomes from metagenomic datasets

fields.name: bin_software
fields.description: Tool(s) used for the extraction of genomes from metagenomic datasets

fields.name: reassembly_bin
fields.description: Has an assembly been performed on a genome bin extracted from a metagenomic assembly?

fields.name: mag_cov_software
fields.description: Tool(s) used to determine the genome coverage if coverage is used as a binning parameter in the extraction of genomes from metagenomic datasets

fields.name: vir_ident_software
fields.description: Tool(s) used for the identification of UViG as a viral genome, software or protocol name including version number, parameters, and cutoffs used

fields.name: pred_genome_type
fields.description: Type of genome predicted for the UViG

fields.name: pred_genome_struc
fields.description: Expected structure of the viral genome

fields.name: detec_type
fields.description: Type of UViG detection

fields.name: otu_class_appr
fields.description: Cutoffs and approach used when clustering new UViGs in "species-level" OTUs. Note that results from standard 95% ANI / 85% AF clustering should be provided alongside OTUS defined from another set of thresholds, even if the latter are the ones primarily used during the analysis

fields.name: otu_seq_comp_appr
fields.description: Tool and thresholds used to compare sequences when computing "species-level" OTUs

fields.name: otu_db
fields.description: Reference database (i.e. sequences not generated as part of the current study) used to cluster new genomes in "species-level" OTUs, if any

fields.name: host_pred_appr
fields.description: Tool or approach used for host prediction

fields.name: host_pred_est_acc
fields.description: For each tool or approach used for host prediction, estimated false discovery rates should be included, either computed de novo or from the literature
fields.examples: CRISPR spacer match: 0 or 1 mismatches, estimated 8% FDR at the host genus rank (Edwards et al. 2016 doi:10.1093/femsre/fuv048)

fields.name: sop
fields.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences

fields.name: pcr_primer_forward
fields.description: Forward PCR primer that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. If multiple multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction, there should be a full row for each of these linked to the same DWC Occurrence. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

fields.name: pcr_primer_reverse
fields.description: Reverse PCR primer that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. If multiple multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction, there should be a full row for each of these linked to the same DWC Occurrence. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

fields.name: pcr_primer_name_forward
fields.description: Name of the forward PCR primer that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. If multiple multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction, there should be a full row for each of these linked to the same DWC Occurrence.

fields.name: pcr_primer_name_reverse
fields.description: Name of the reverse PCR primer that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. If multiple multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction, there should be a full row for each of these linked to the same DWC Occurrence.

fields.name: pcr_primer_reference
fields.description: Reference for the PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment.

fields.name: DNA_sequence
fields.description: The DNA sequence

fields.name: concentration
fields.description: Concentration of DNA (weight ng/volume µl)

fields.name: concentrationUnit
fields.description: Unit used for concentration measurement

fields.name: methodDeterminationConcentrationAndRatios
fields.description: Description of method used for concentration measurement

fields.name: ratioOfAbsorbance260_230
fields.description: Ratio of absorbance at 260 nm and 230 nm assessing DNA purity (mostly secondary measure, indicates mainly EDTA, carbohydrates, phenol), (DNA samples only).

fields.name: ratioOfAbsorbance260_280
fields.description: Ratio of absorbance at 280 nm and 230 nm assessing DNA purity (mostly secondary measure, indicates mainly EDTA, carbohydrates, phenol), (DNA samples only).

fields.name: annealingTemp
fields.description: The reaction temperature during the annealing phase of PCR.

fields.name: annealingTempUnit
fields.description: Measurement unit of the reaction temperature during the annealing phase of PCR.

fields.name: probeReporter
fields.description: Type of fluorophore (reporter) used. Probe anneals within amplified target DNA. Polymerase activity degrades the probe that has annealed to the template, and the probe releases the fluorophore from it and breaks the proximity to the quencher, thus allowing fluorescence of the fluorophore.

fields.name: probeQuencher
fields.description: Type of quencher used. The quencher molecule quenches the fluorescence emitted by the fluorophore when excited by the cycler’s light source As long as fluorophore and the quencher are in proximity, quenching inhibits any fluorescence signals.

fields.name: ampliconSize
fields.description: The length of the amplicon in basepairs.

fields.name: thresholdQuantificationCycle
fields.description: Threshold for change in fluorescence signal between cycles

fields.name: baselineValue
fields.description: The number of cycles when fluorescence signal from the target amplification is below background fluorescence not originated from the real target amplification.

fields.name: quantificationCycle
fields.description: The number of cycles required for the fluorescent signal to cross a given value threshold above the baseline. Quantification cycle (Cq), threshold cycle (Ct), crossing point (Cp), and take-off point (TOP) refer to the same value from the real-time instrument. Use of quantification cycle (Cq), is preferable according to the RDML (Real-Time PCR Data Markup Language) data standard (http://www.rdml.org).

fields.name: automaticThresholdQuantificationCycle
fields.description: Whether the threshold was set by the instrument or manually.

fields.name: automaticBaselineValue
fields.description: Whether the baseline value was set by the instrument or manually.

fields.name: contaminationAssessment
fields.description: Whether DNA or RNA contamination assessment was done or not.

fields.name: partitionVolume
fields.description: An accurate estimation of partition volume. The sum of the partitions multiplied by the partition volume will enable the total volume of the reaction to be calculated.

fields.name: partitionVolumeUnit
fields.description: Unit used for partition volume

fields.name: estimatedNumberOfCopies
fields.description: Number of target molecules per µl. Mean copies per partition (?) can be calculated using the number of partitions (n) and the estimated copy number in the total volume of all partitions (m) with a formula ?=m/n.

fields.name: amplificationReactionVolume
fields.description: PCR reaction volume

fields.name: amplificationReactionVolumeUnit
fields.description: Unit used for PCR reaction volume. Many of the instruments require preparation of a much larger initial sample volume than is actually analyzed.

fields.name: pcr_analysis_software
fields.description: The program used to analyse the d(d)PCR runs.

fields.name: experimentalVariance
fields.description: Multiple biological replicates are encouraged to assess total experimental variation. When single dPCR experiments are performed, a minimal estimate of variance due to counting error alone must be calculated from the binomial (or suitable equivalent) distribution.

fields.name: pcr_primer_lod
fields.description: The assay’s ability to detect the target at low levels.

fields.name: pcr_primer_loq
fields.description: The assay’s ability to quantify copy number at low levels.

fields.name: agentID
fields.description: An identifier for an Agent.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: geneticSequenceID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticSequence.

fields.name: agentRole
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of a role of an Agent.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary for the roles appropriate to the class of resource an AgentRole is related to.

fields.name: agentRoleIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the role of an Agent.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: agentRoleVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in agentRole is given.

fields.name: agentRoleOrder
fields.description: The numerical position of an AgentRole in a set of AgentRoles that have the same combination of agentRole, agentRoleIRI, agentRoleVocabulary and related target.
fields.comments: One could use agentRoleOrder to create an ordered list of collectors (agentRole = 'collector') for a dwc:MaterialEntity, for example. The first would have agentRoleOrder=1, the second would have agentRoleOrder=2.

fields.name: agentRoleDate
fields.description: The interval during which an AgentRole was in effect.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: assertionID
fields.description: An identifier for an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: geneticSequenceID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticSequence.

fields.name: assertionType
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of an Assertion.
fields.examples: `mass`; `mean mass`; `weight standard deviation`; `minimum organism quantity`; `water temperature`; `salinity`

fields.name: assertionTypeIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionTypeVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in assertionType is given.

fields.name: assertionMadeDate
fields.description: The date on which an Assertion was created.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: assertionEffectiveDate
fields.description: The date on which the state or measurement of an Assertion was deemed to first be in effect.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: assertionValue
fields.description: An asserted value, if it is not numeric.

fields.name: assertionValueIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the value of an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionValueVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in assertionValue is given.

fields.name: assertionValueNumeric
fields.description: An asserted value, if it is numeric.

fields.name: assertionUnit
fields.description: The units associated with the value in assertionValueNumeric.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Ontology of Units of Measure http://www.wurvoc.org/vocabularies/om-1.8/ of SI units, derived units, or other non-SI units accepted for use within the SI. For units that are composed of multiple parts, use the patterns as given in "A Primer for Communicating Mathematics via Plain Text" (https://cse.sc.edu/~fenner/latex-ASCII.pdf) by Stephen Fenner (e.g., `g/cm^3` for grams per cubic centimeter). For other units, provide the value as a recognizable standard (e.g., '%') or written out in full and in the plural (e.g., `individuals`). It is fine to provide non-SI units in the original language of the dataset.

fields.name: assertionUnitIRI
fields.description: The IRI for the units of an assertionValueNumeric.

fields.name: assertionUnitVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in assertionUnit is given.

fields.name: assertionBy
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who made an Assertion.
fields.examples: `José E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson`; `FMNH`

fields.name: assertionByID
fields.description: An identifier for an Agent who made an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
fields.examples: `https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097` (for an individual); `https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097 | https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0098` (for a list of people)

fields.name: assertionProtocol
fields.description: The names of, references to, or descriptions of the methods or protocols used in making an Assertion.

fields.name: assertionProtocolID
fields.description: An identifier for a Protocol used to make an Assertion.

fields.name: assertionCitation
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261`; `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

fields.name: assertionRemarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about an Assertion.

fields.name: citationID
fields.description: An identifier for a Citation.

fields.name: geneticSequenceID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticSequence.

fields.name: citationType
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of a Citation.

fields.name: citationTypeIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of Citation.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: citationTypeVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in citationType is given.

fields.name: bibliographicCitation
fields.description: A bibliographic reference for the resource.
fields.comments: From Dublin Core, 'Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible.' The intended usage of this term in Darwin Core is to provide the preferred way to cite the resource itself. Note that the intended usage of dcterms:references in Darwin Core, by contrast, is to point to the definitive source representation of the resource, if one is available.
fields.examples: `Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, UC Berkeley. MVZ Mammal Collection (Arctos). Record ID: http://arctos.database.museum/guid/MVZ:Mamm:165861?seid=101356. Source: http://ipt.vertnet.org:8080/ipt/resource.do?r=mvz_mammal.` (Occurrence example); `https://www.gbif.org/species/2439608 Source: GBIF Taxonomic Backbone` (Taxon example); `Rand, K.M., Logerwell, E.A. The first demersal trawl survey of benthic fish and invertebrates in the Beaufort Sea since the late 1970s. Polar Biol 34, 475–488 (2011). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00300-010-0900-2` (Event example)

fields.name: pageNumber
fields.description: The number of the page on which the citation occurs in the cited reference.
fields.comments: From Dublin Core, 'Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible.' The intended usage of this term in Darwin Core is to provide the preferred way to cite the resource itself. Note that the intended usage of dcterms:references in Darwin Core, by contrast, is to point to the definitive source representation of the resource, if one is available.

fields.name: referenceID
fields.description: An identifier for the reference in which a Citation occurs.

fields.name: referenceType
fields.description: The category that best matches the nature of a reference.

fields.name: referenceTypeIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the type of reference.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: referenceTypeVocabulary
fields.description: The reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in referenceType is given.

fields.name: referenceYear
fields.description: The year the reference in a Citation was published.

fields.name: isPeerReviewed
fields.description: An indication of whether the reference for a Citation was peer reviewed.

fields.name: citationRemarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a Citation.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.description: An identifier for a Media instance.

fields.name: geneticSequenceID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticSequence.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategory
fields.description: A term to describe the content of the image by a value from a controlled vocabulary.
fields.comments: Controlled vocabulary of subjects to support broad classification of media items. Terms from various controlled vocabularies may be used. AC-recommended vocabularies are preferred and MAY be unqualified literals (not a full URI). For terms from other vocabularies either a precise URI SHOULD be used, or, as long as all unqualified terms in all vocabularies are unique, metadata SHOULD provide the source vocabularies using the Subject Category Vocabulary term. The value SHOULD be a string, whose text can also be in the form of a URL. These guidelines on value format are less restrictive than is specified by the IPTC guidelines.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategoryIRI
fields.description: The IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for the subject category of the Media instance.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategoryVocabulary
fields.description: Any vocabulary or formal classification from which terms in the Subject Category have been drawn.
fields.comments: The AC recommended vocabularies do not need to be cited here. There is no required linkage between individual Subject Category terms and the vocabulary; the mechanism is intended to support discovery of the normative URI for a term, but not guarantee it.

fields.name: geneticSequenceID
fields.description: An identifier for a GeneticSequence.

fields.name: geneticSequence
fields.description: A string representing nucleotide base pairs.

fields.name: geneticSequenceRemarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a GeneticSequence.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.description: An identifier for a Media instance.

fields.name: geologicalContextID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:GeologicalContext.
